title: Question 58

children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea but no nausea or vomiting. Medical history is significant for end-stage liver disease secondary to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis for which he received a liver transplant 4 months ago. Medications are mycophenolate, prednisone, and tacrolimus.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °F), blood pressure is 98/64 mm Hg, pulse rate is 122/min, and respiration rate is 17/min. The lungs are clear. The abdomen is distended with diffuse tenderness but no guarding or hepatosplenomegaly. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following viruses is the most likely cause of the patient's illness?

Cytomegalovirus is a significant pathogen in solid organ transplant recipients and can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, colitis with bloody diarrhea, esophagitis, and adrenalitis.
Cytomegalovirus is most likely responsible for this patient's illness (

). Approximately 60% to 90% of adults have latent cytomegalovirus infection, with reactivation of disease common in persons who are immunosuppressed (e.g., patients with AIDS, transplant recipients, patients taking glucocorticoids). Cytomegalovirus is a significant pathogen in solid organ transplant recipients. The risk of cytomegalovirus infection is highest when a seronegative recipient (one who has never had a cytomegalovirus infection) receives a solid organ from a seropositive donor. Cytomegalovirus can cause retinitis (especially in persons with AIDS), pneumonitis, hepatitis, bone marrow suppression, colitis with bloody diarrhea (such as in this patient), esophagitis, and adrenalitis. This patient underwent liver transplantation and has bloody diarrhea consistent with cytomegalovirus reactivation. Diagnosis relies on isolation of the virus from bodily fluids, such as serum; detection of cytomegalovirus p65 antigen in leukocytes; cytopathic demonstration of “owl's eye” intracellular inclusions from tissue biopsy; polymerase chain reaction; and serologic assays.

PTLD risk is higher in patients with a history of pre-existing EBV infection treated with lymphocyte-depleting agents and in those receiving sirolimus and tacrolimus compared with those receiving mycophenolate and cyclosporine. This patient has no generalized lymphadenopathy or hepatosplenomegaly, and bloody diarrhea is not a common presentation of PTLD.
